docs.snippet: TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I am a taxi driver, aged 32, married and with one child. I'm a good, steady worker; I'm strong and in good health. I am very eager to improve my own economic position and also to be of real service to my count...
docs.lead_paragraph: TO THE EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES : I am a taxi driver, aged 32, married and with one child. I'm a good, steady worker; I'm strong and in good health. I am very eager to improve my own economic position and also to be of real service to my country by becoming a skilled worker in one of the industries which are essential to the rearmament program.

headline.main: Travis Bickle, Still Asking If Someone's Talking to Him

docs.snippet: On its 20th anniversary, the prophetic masterpiece of the 1970's looks better than ever. Hindsight underscores the amazing prescience of Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver," a film that anticipated such profound changes in our national mood. Since its...
docs.lead_paragraph: On its 20th anniversary, the prophetic masterpiece of the 1970's looks better than ever. Hindsight underscores the amazing prescience of Martin Scorsese's "Taxi Driver," a film that anticipated such profound changes in our national mood. Since its debut, "Taxi Driver" and Travis Bickle, a tortured innocent dpiven over the brink into shocking violence, have come to seem far less marginal than they did in 1976. The spiritual perils invoked by Paul Schrader's daring, cautionary screenplay have come closer to home. Yet for all its invective against urban decay, "Taxi Driver" is also brilliantly acted and rhapsodically beautiful, which accounts for so much of its staying power. Mr. Scorsese's vision of a shimmering, neon-lighted purgatory remains as haunting as ever, thanks also to the power of Bernard Herrmann's unforgettable score. The stunning New York of "Taxi Driver" still looks both seductive and terrible, a physical manifestation of the forces tearing Travis apart.

docs.abstract: Kathy Ryan What They Were Thinking interview with Jodie Foster and her sister Connie, who are depicted in a photograph taken by Steve Schapiro on the set of the movie Taxi Driver; photo (M)

headline.main: Sisters on a movie Set, New York, 1975

docs.snippet: Jodie Foster (right): I was thinking what a dumb thing it was to put my sister in an outfit to be my double in ''Taxi Driver.'' The child-welfare bureau had decided that a 12-year-old playing a part with such sexuality was a problem and insisted o...
docs.lead_paragraph: Jodie Foster (right): I was thinking what a dumb thing it was to put my sister in an outfit to be my double in ''Taxi Driver.'' The child-welfare bureau had decided that a 12-year-old playing a part with such sexuality was a problem and insisted on a double for any shots that were physically suggestive. So my mom said: ''I've got a great idea. Why don't we bring your sister?'' But honestly, what did that accomplish? Did they think that I was too young to understand the script; that I couldn't delineate between being a prostitute and a regular person? But it was a really good excuse to have my sister hanging out with me in New York.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:   What is needed is to have every taxi cab driver and all new drivers go to London and Geneva and ride the taxis there to see how the job is done right -- or, at least, have management make the trip. Drivers in those cities know the...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: What is needed is to have every taxi cab driver and all new drivers go to London and Geneva and ride the taxis there to see how the job is done right -- or, at least, have management make the trip. Drivers in those cities know the territory very well, they are neat, clean and well dressed and they keep their taxis neat and clean. STEWART M. LEE Beaver Falls, Pa., Aug. 22

docs.abstract: David Thompson compares new Martin Scorsese film Bringing Out the Dead starring Nicolas Cage and Patricia Arquette with his earlier works, particularly Taxi Driver; photo (M)

headline.main: An Offering to the Ghosts of Wildness Past

docs.snippet: THERE are sparking synapses all through ''Bringing Out the Dead.'' You're wondering whether you're bored stiff or flatlining when, like a match in film noir, the screen flares into life. Nicolas Cage and Patricia Arquette sit down together and a r...
docs.lead_paragraph: THERE are sparking synapses all through ''Bringing Out the Dead.'' You're wondering whether you're bored stiff or flatlining when, like a match in film noir, the screen flares into life. Nicolas Cage and Patricia Arquette sit down together and a riff in the editing makes her look like the head on an Etruscan coin. It's a glimpse of Godardian eternity in the rowdy Manhattan night. Or take the jittery progress of the ambulance, with the street turning 90 degrees, so that the wash of sunset looks like light at the end of a tunnel. Or the slow whitening out of the last shot and its perilous calm, so lovely it nearly equals the lush shot of a woman dead at her own threshold, her hair fanned out and the wine of blood reaching farther still, floating on the overflow of her bath.
